maml:description.maml:para: Returns information about Network Interface Cards.
Returns information about legacy and/or VMbus Network Interface Cards on one or more Virtual Machine(s).

The Virtual Machine(s) to query. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is specified the information will be returned for all VMs on the server. If no VM is specified, NICs from all VMs Will be returned.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
Select legacy (emulated) NICs. If the user specifies both -legacy and -VMbus OR neither then all types of NIC Will be returned.
Select VM-Bus(synthetic) NICs. If the user specifies both -legacy and -VMbus OR neither then all types of NIC Will be returned.

The Virtual Machine(s) to query. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is specified, NICs from all VMs Will be returned.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
Select legacy (emulated) NICs. If the user specifies both -legacy and -VMbus OR neither then all types of NIC Will be returned.
Select VM-Bus(synthetic) NICs. If the user specifies both -legacy and -VMbus OR neither then all types of NIC Will be returned.
VMs can be piped into GetVMNIC.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns both Legacy and VMbus NICs found on the VM pointed to by $core.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns one or more Virtual Switch objects.
If no name is specified returns all the Virtual Network Switches on a host, Otherwise returns the switch(es) which match the given name.

The name of a Switch being sought (which may include wildcards.) WMI queries use % as a wildcard, but the command will convert * to %. Name can be used as an Alias for VirtualSwitchName (as well as contractions of it).
Specifies the Hyper-V server(s) to search for the switch(es) By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.

The name of a Switch being sought (which may include wildcards.) WMI queries use % as a wildcard, but the command will convert * to % Name can be used as an Alias for VirtualSwitchName (as well as contractions of it).
Specifies the Hyper-V server(s) to search for the switch(es). By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
Names can be passed via the pipe.
MsVM_VirtualSwitch WMI object(s) representing the switches.
Returns the switch port object for a Network Interface Card.
Returns the switch port object for a Network Interface Card: This is the logical port on a switch, not the switch itself. It can be used to find the switch.
An object representing the a Network Interface Card whose port is sought.
An object representing the a Network Interface Card whose port is sought.
The NIC object.
The Switch port object associated with the noc.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns the switch-ports on the NICs of the VM pointed to by $core.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns the switch connected to a a Network Interface Card.
Returns the WMI object representing the Virtual Network Switch connected to a Network Interface Card.
An object representing the a Network Interface Card whose switch is sought.
An object representing the a Network Interface Card whose switch is sought.
The NIC object.
The Switch port object associated with the noc.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns names of Switches used by the VM pointed to by $core.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new legacy or VM-bus Network Interface Card on a Virtual Machine.
Creates a new Network Interface Card on a virtual machine. It can create Legacy (emulated) or VM-bus (Synthetic) NICs, assign a fixed MAC address, and specify the GUID which identifies a VM-bus NIC.

The Virtual Machine(s) to modify. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.

The Virtual switch to connect. This may be a WMI object representing a switch or a string object containing the name of a switch (if a wildcard is used it must resolve to a single switch). If not specified, the new NIC is created in a disconnected state.
MAC address. If not specified the Network card will be assigned a MAC address automatically, the first time it is used.
VM-Bus NICS are identified by a GUID. If a new VM is created, using an existing VHD file the OS in the VM will see a new NIC unless the original GUID is used.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
Create a legacy (emulated) NIC. If not specified a VM-bus (Synthetic) NIC Will be created.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.

The Virtual Machine(s) to modify. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.

The Virtual switch to connect. This may be a WMI object representing a switch or a string object containing the name of a switch (if a wildcard is used it must resolve to a single switch). If not specified, the new NIC is created in a disconnected state.
MAC address. If not specified the Network card will be assigned a MAC address automatically, the first time it is used.
VM-Bus NICS are identified by a GUID. If a new VM is created, using an existing VHD file the OS in the VM will see a new NIC unless the original GUID is used.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
Create a legacy (emulated) NIC. If not specified a VM-Bus (Synthetic) NIC Will be created.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc, with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
VMs can be piped into Add-VMNic.
A WMI object representing the new NIC.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a VM-bus nic to the VM pointed to by $core , choosing the connection from a list of switches.
Adds a legacy nic to the VM named Tenby on the local server, choosing the connection from a list of switches.

command:example.maml:title: ----- Example 3 -----
command:example.dev:code: get-VM core-% -Server James-2008 | add-VMnic -virtualSwitch "Internal Virtual Network" -legacy

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a legacy nic to those VMs on Server James-2008 which have names beginning Core- and binds them to the "Internal virtual network" switch.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a Network Interface Card from a VM.
Removes a Network Interface Card from a VM.
The NIC to remove from the VM.
The VM does not need to be passed to the function (it is determined from the NIC) but is retained for compatibility reasons.
The Server does not need to be passed to the function (it is determined from the NIC) but is retained for compatibility reasons.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
The NIC to remove from the VM.
The VM does not need to be passed to the function (it is determined from the NIC) but is retained for compatibility reasons.
The Server does not need to be passed to the function (it is determined from the NIC) but is retained for compatibility reasons.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc, with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
NIC objects may be Piped into Remove VMNic.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes a NIC on server pointed to by $core, if there are multiple NICs the user will prompted to select one.
Gets all the legacy NICS on virtual machines with names beginning “Lab” and removes them without prompting.

maml:description.maml:para: Allows the user to select a Network Interface Cards connected to a VM.
If a VM has only a single Network Interface Card, that NIC will be returned. If it has more than one, a list will be displayed to allow the user to make a selection.

The Virtual Machine(s) to query. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is specified, NICs from all VMs Will be returned.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
If specified allows the user to select multiple NICs. This is particularly useful when multiple VMs are specified.

The Virtual Machine(s) to query. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is specified, NICs from all VMs Will be returned.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
If specified allows the user to select multiple NICs. This is particularly useful when multiple VMs are specified.
VMs can be piped into Select-VMNic.
The Selected NIC.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Allows the user to choose a single NIC from the NICs on the VM pointed to by $core.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns a Virtual Switch objects.
If only one switch is found on a server, it is returned, if more than one exists a list is provided to allow the user to make a selection.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which the switches reside. By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which the switches reside. By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
Names can be passed via the pipe.
MsVM_VirtualSwitch.
Returns a newly created Switch port.
This command is intended to be called by other commands, and not directly from the command line.
The Virtual switch to connect. This may be a WMI object representing a switch or a string object containing the name of a switch (if a wildcard is used it must resolve to a single switch).
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which the a named switch is found. By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
The Virtual switch to connect. This may be a WMI object representing a switch or a string object containing the name of a switch (if a wildcard is used it must resolve to a single switch).
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which the a named switch is found. By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
A switch can be passed via the pipe.
The Newly created port.

maml:alert.maml:para: Not intended to be called directly, used by Add-VMNIC and SetVMNICConnection.

maml:description.maml:para: Changes the MAC address of a Network Interface Card.

Normally the MAC address of a new Network Interface Card is set the next time its VM boots. The address is assigned from a range held by the server which hosts the VM However the address can be set or changed manually.
An object representing the NIC to be modified.
MAC address. This must be 12 Hex digits.
The VM does not need to be passed to the function (it is determined from the NIC) but is retained for compatibility reasons.
The Server does not need to be passed to the function (it is determined from the NIC) but is retained for compatibility reasons.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc, with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
An object representing the NIC to be modified.
MAC address. This must be 12 Hex digits.
The VM does not need to be passed to the function (it is determined from the NIC) but is retained for compatibility reasons.
The Server does not need to be passed to the function (it is determined from the NIC) but is retained for compatibility reasons.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc, with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
A WMI object describing the NIC may be piped into Set-VMNICAddress.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the MAC address of a NIC on the pointed to by $core, if there are multiple NICs the user will prompted to select one.
An alternative way to write example 1

maml:description.maml:para: Connects a Network Interface Card to a Virtual switch.
Connects a Virtual Network Interface Card to a different a virtual switch. If no switch is specified, the NIC is disconnected.
The NIC to Modify.
The Virtual switch to connect. This may be a WMI object representing a switch or a string object containing the name of a switch (if a wildcard is used it must resolve to a single switch).

dev:remarks.maml:para: Connects a NIC on the VM pointed to by $core, If there are multiple NICs the user will prompted to select one, and they will be prompted to select a switch if there is more than one.
An alternative way of writing example 1.

maml:description.maml:para: Selects an avaialable host network Interface.

When an external virtual network switch is created it needs to be told which network interface on the host computer it should be bound to. If there is more than one available, a list is presented to allow the user to make a selection.
Specifies the Hyper-V server to query for network interfaces By default "." , the local computer is used.
Specifies the Hyper-V server to query for network interfaces By default "." , the local computer is used.
The selected external ethernet port.
Creates a virtual network switch, which isn't bound to a NIC in the parent partition.
Creates a virtual network switch, which isn't bound to a NIC in the parent partition.
The name for the new switch.
The number of ports to be created on the new switch.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
The name for the new switch.
The number of ports to be created on the new switch.
Specifies the Hyper-V server to query for network interfaces By default "." , the local computer is used.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a Switch on the server named "HVCore". The network will not be accessible in the host OS, and will be named "VM Network" in the Hyper-V administration tools.

The name for the new switch.
The number of ports to be created on the new switch.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a Switch and virtual NIC in the host. The device name for the NIC in the host and the Network name in Hyper-V will be "Host and VM Network".

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes a virtual network switch.
Deletes a virtual network switch.
A string containing the name for the switch to be deleted, or a WMI object representing the switch. It may be passed via the pipe.

THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc, with nested and recursive calls to the command.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a virtual network switch, bound to a physical network card.
Creates a virtual network switch, and binds it to a network card which is available in the parent partition.
The name for the new switch.
Either the name of a Network interface, passed as a string, or a WMI object representing an interface. It may be passed via the pipe.
The number of ports to be created on the new switch.
Specifies the Hyper-V server where the switch should be created By default "." , the local computer is used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc, with nested and recursive calls to the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Allows the user to choose if there are multiple available NICs and binds the selected one to a new switch. The device name for the NIC in created in the host and the Network name in Hyper-V will be "Wired virtual Network".

Finds a Nic with a name beginning "Broadcom" on the server named "core", and binds it to a new switch. The device name for the NIC in created in the host and the Network name in Hyper-V will be "Wired virtual Network".

maml:description.maml:para: Discovers which VM owns a particular mac address.
The MAC address to seek. The command uses regular expression matching, so a partial address or regex can be used in the MAC field.
Specifies the Hyper-V server(s) to search for a matching NIC By default "." , the local computer is used. An array of server names by be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
The MAC address to seek. The command uses regular expression matching so a partial address or regex can be used in the MAC field.

Mac address can be piped into Get-VMByMACaddress.
the associated VM.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns details of the VM with the NIC given the address 00155D000101.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new port on a virtual network switch.
Creates a new port on a virtual network switch.
Either the name of a Network switch, passed as a string, or a WMI object representing an interface. It may be passed via the pipeline.
The identifier for the port, this is normally a GUID and will be created automatically if not passed as a parameter.
Specifies the Hyper-V server to query for a network switch, if the switch is passed as a name. By default "." , the local computer is used.
Either the name of a Network switch, passed as a string, or a WMI object representing an interface. It may be passed via the pipeline.
The identifier for the port, this is normally a GUID and will be created automatically if not passed as a parameter.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the parent partition NIC associated with a Virtual switch.

Removes the parent partition Network Interface Card associated with a Virtual switch. A virtual NIC is always created in the parent partition for internal and external networks. In Hyper-V R2 there is an option to not allow a management partition to access the an external NIC used by VMs. The same result can be achieved by using remove-VMswitchNic.
The name of the NIC to be removed.
Specifies the Hyper-V server to query for the NIC . By default "." , the local computer is used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc, with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").
The name of the NIC to be removed.
Specifies the Hyper-V server to query for the NIC . By default "." , the local computer is used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").

maml:alert.maml:para: This is intended to be called from other commands, and not from the command line.
